bibl.title: Letter from George K. Strode to Frederick F. Russell, January 22, 1924

div1.p: Strode informs Russell of some lab work that was done with cultures from yellow fever patients. Noguchi is almost finished with his mission in Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from George K. Strode to Frederick F. Russell, January 22, 1924
div1.opener:
COPY
COMMISSAO ROCKEFELLER
January 22, 1924
Dear Doctor Russell:-
div1.p:
Doubtless Doctor Noguchi has already advised you regarding the
success which has come with his work in Bahia. Repitition on my part will do
no harm.

Early in January one of the Brazilian physicians, attached to Doctor
Noguchi, returned from a trip to an interior city called Palmeiras, which is
between three and four hundred kilometers from the capital. The physician brought
back with him inoculated culture tubes from five cases of clinical yellow fever.
These tubes were examined by the staff of the Oswaldo Cruz Institute in Bahia
and at the time of Doctor Noguchi's letter to me (January 8th) one of the cases
showed the presence of leptospira in two out of the six tubes inoculated.
Pfeiffer reaction was performed on this strain with the serums of convalescents
from yellow fever in 1923 and was found positive. Animal experiments are now in
progress and Doctor Noguchi feels that his mission in Brazil is about finished
and that he will be starting back home via the northern States of Brazil about
the middle of February.

I am also attaching hereto a translation of a newspaper article
pertaining to Doctor Noguchi which appeared in last night's Rio paper.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) George K. Strode GKS:Ah
Doctor F. F. Russell, Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York
Enclosure.
